item.title: Scientists Discover Common Virus Could Be Causing a Type of Alzheimer's - ScienceAlert
item.description:
Scientists Discover Common Virus Could Be Causing a Type of Alzheimer's

Publication Date: 2024-12-19 Source: Science Alert

Researchers have discovered a link between a chronic gut infection caused by a common virus and the development of Alzheimer's disease in some individuals.

  • The study identifies cytomegalovirus (CMV) as a potential causal factor in Alzheimer’s disease, particularly in a specific subset of individuals.
  • By age 80, 90% of people will have antibodies for CMV, but only a small subset experiences chronic intestinal infection.
  • The active virus may travel up the gut-brain axis, aggravating the immune system and potentially leading to Alzheimer’s.
  • Researchers are exploring antiviral treatments to potentially prevent this subtype of Alzheimer’s.
"We think we found a biologically unique subtype of Alzheimer's that may affect 25 percent to 45 percent of people with this disease," said Ben Readhead, lead author from Arizona State University.

This research highlights the need for further investigation into the relationship between chronic infections and neurodegenerative diseases.

item.title: Pupil Dynamics During Sleep Reveal Brain’s Memory-Saving Secrets - Neuroscience News
item.description:
Pupil Dynamics During Sleep Reveal Brain’s Memory-Saving Secrets

Date: January 1, 2023
Source: Cornell University

Researchers at Cornell University have found that pupil size during non-REM sleep plays a crucial role in memory consolidation. This study demonstrates that contracted pupils correlate with the consolidation of new memories, while dilated pupils relate to the processing of older memories.

  • Pupil Size and Memory: Contracted pupils correlate with new memory consolidation, while dilated pupils process older memories.
  • Memory Separation: The brain alternates between new and old knowledge during non-REM sleep to prevent interference.
  • AI Applications: Insights into memory processing may help improve efficiency in artificial neural networks.
The eyes may be the window to the soul, but the pupil is key to understanding how, and when, the brain forms strong, long-lasting memories, Cornell researchers have found.

The findings offer potential for developing better memory enhancement techniques and deeper understanding of sleep's role in memory processing.

item.title: Even small amounts of alcohol can cause cancer, bottles should have warning: US Surgeon General - Hindustan Times
item.description:
US Surgeon General Calls for Cancer Warning Labels on Alcoholic Beverages

Date: Jan 05, 2025 | Source: Hindustan Times

The US Surgeon General, Dr. Vivek Murthy, has recommended that alcoholic beverages carry warning labels due to their link to cancer, highlighting the risks even from moderate drinking.

  • The advisory emphasizes that alcohol is the third leading preventable cause of cancer in the US.
  • Approximately 20,000 cancer-related deaths annually are attributed to alcohol, with 17% from those who drink within recommended limits.
  • Less than half of Americans are aware of the alcohol-cancer connection.
  • Alcohol consumption is linked to at least seven types of cancer.
  • The call for warning labels has received mixed reactions from health organizations and industry representatives.
“What we know with a high degree of confidence is that there is a causal link between alcohol and cancer risk. The data has been building for some time and getting stronger and stronger.” - Dr. Vivek Murthy

The Surgeon General's advisory on warning labels seeks to enhance public awareness about the health risks associated with alcohol, targeting a product widely consumed in the US.

item.title: Antibiotic emergency ‘could claim 40 million lives in next 25 years’ - The Guardian
item.description:
Antibiotic Emergency Could Claim 40 Million Lives in the Next 25 Years

Publication Date: Not specified | Source: Observer

Dame Sally Davies warns that the alarming rise of antimicrobial resistance (AMR) poses a serious threat to global health and could significantly increase mortality rates over the next 25 years.

  • AMR leads to about a million deaths annually, with projections estimating that figure could rise to 40 million over the next quarter-century.
  • Mortality rates from AMR have increased by 80% in individuals aged over 70 since 1990.
  • Around 70% of antibiotics are used in livestock, exacerbating the resistance problem.
  • The lack of new antibiotic classes since the late 1980s highlights the need for urgent innovation in antibiotic development.
“It is really scary.” - Dame Sally Davies

The growing crisis of AMR necessitates immediate global action to prevent further escalation and protect vulnerable populations.
